Fidel Title: Co-Founder, Corporate Development Date:  8/16/20_6| 10:07 EDT Con-08310 sarf_229438 14 FOR LEGAL USE ONLY CJK DocuSign Envelope ID: BE5C1D8E-3077-44DC-8729-290D2091EB8F EXHIBIT 1 CUSTOMER SERVICE LEVEL AGREEMENT (“SLA”) For RiskSense® EFFECTIVE DATE: The effective date of this SLA is the date in which the service is initiated. This RiskSense® Platform Service Level Agreement (“SLA”) is a policy governing the use of RiskSense® under the terms of the RiskSense® EULA Agreement (the “EULA Agreement”) between RiskSense, Inc., (“HOST”, “us” or “we”) and users (“you” or “Customer”) of the RiskSense® services. This SLA applies separately to each RiskSense® platform deployment. Unless otherwise provided herein, this SLA is subject to the terms of the EULA Agreement and capitalized terms will have the meaning specified in the EULA Agreement. We reserve the right to change the terms of this SLA in accordance with the EULA Agreement. Support Services & General Assistance HOST will provide unlimited off-site support by trained personnel during Normal Support Hours on the use and maintenance of the Software. The Normal Support Hours for the HOST are 8:00am to 5:00pm MST/MDT Monday through Friday. Such support may be provided via electronic mail, toll- free telephone service, facsimile, public bulletin boards, and/or other similar methods. Any Remedies for non-performance are set forth below under Service Availability Guarantee. Response Times HOST will endeavor to provide maintenance and support to CUSTOMER at the time of the call but in any event no later than the following, based on the priority of the problem. Critical Priority - Software is Unavailable. Within sixty (60) minutes following CUSTOMER’s reporting of a Critical problem, HOST will respond and provide an assessment or evaluation of the problem. Thereafter, HOST will diligently perform corrective maintenance upon the Software. HOST will continue such efforts until the Software is restored to operate in conformity with the documentation, available within RiskSense. Urgent Priority- A major feature1 of the Software is non-functional with no reasonable workaround. Within two (2) hours during the HOST’s Normal Support Hours following CUSTOMER’s reporting of an Urgent problem, HOST will respond and provide an assessment or evaluation of the problem. Thereafter HOST will diligently perform corrective maintenance upon the Software. HOST will continue such efforts until the Software is restored to operate in conformity with the documentation, available within RiskSense. 1 Based upon an Customer’s end-user’s role and responsibility, there may be varying definitions of what constitutes a major or minor feature. In the event where a feature is non-functional, the Customer should initiate a support ticket within RiskSense. Con-08310 sarf_229438 15 FOR LEGAL USE ONLY CJK DocuSign Envelope ID: BE5C1D8E-3077-44DC-8729-290D2091EB8F Standard Priority- A major feature of the Software is non-functional, but there is a reasonable workaround or a non-major feature is unavailable with no reasonable workaround. Within two (2) hours during the HOST’s Normal Support Hours following CUSTOMER’S reporting of a Standard Priority problem, HOST will respond and provide an assessment or evaluation of the problem. Thereafter HOST will diligently perform corrective maintenance upon the Software. HOST will continue such efforts until the Software is restored to operate in conformity with the documentation, available within RiskSense. Low Priority- An enhancement is called for or there is a minor problem that does not materially interrupt or disrupt work. HOST will respond within two (2) hours during the HOST’s Normal Support Hours following CUSTOMER’s reporting of a Low Priority problem. HOST will respond and either resolve the problem or agree to provide an acceptable workaround in future commercial releases or error corrections during HOST’s normal course of business. SERVICE AVAILABILITY GUARANTEE The Vendor will use all reasonable efforts to make RiskSense® available within its current operational environment within the AWS GovCloud (US) services with a Monthly Uptime Percentage (defined below) of at least 99.5%, in each SaaS deployment during any monthly billing cycle (the “Service Commitment”). In the event the Vendor does not meet the Service Commitment as described below, the CUSTOMER will be eligible to receive a Service Credit. SLA DEFINITIONS • “Monthly Uptime Percentage” is calculated by subtracting from 100% the percentage of minutes during the month in which RiskSense® was “Unavailable.” Monthly Uptime Percentage measurements will exclude downtime resulting from any “Predefined Maintenance Period.” o Less than 99.5% but equal to or greater than 95.0% 5% Service Credit o Less than 95.0% but equal to or greater than 90% 10% Service Credit o Less than 90% 15% Service Credit • “Unavailable” and “Outage” is defined as the Customer’s data within the RiskSense Platform as non-accessible. This means a Critical Priority (as defined by the EULA for RiskSense®) has occurred. The following conditions are excluded from the Outage definition: o Any issues on the CUSTOMER network that causes the users not to be able to access the platform, shall not be considered as an Outage o Any issues caused by factors outside of our reasonable control, including any force majeure event or Internet access or related problems beyond the demarcation point of the AWS GovCloud (US) environment. Con-08310 sarf_229438 16 FOR LEGAL USE ONLY CJK DocuSign Envelope ID: BE5C1D8E-3077-44DC-8729-290D2091EB8F • A “Service Credit” is a dollar credit, calculated as set forth below, that we may credit back to an eligible account. Service Credits are calculated as a percentage of the total monthly charges paid by you during the current billing cycle (excluding any one-time payments). o We will apply any Service Credits only against future RiskSense® payments otherwise due from the CUSTOMER. Service Credits will not entitle the CUSTOMER to any refund or other payment from the Vendor. A Service Credit will be applicable and issued only if the credit amount for the applicable monthly billing cycle is greater than one dollar ($1 USD). Service Credits may not be transferred or applied to any other account. Unless otherwise provided in the SaaS Agreement, the CUSTOMER’s sole and exclusive remedy for any unavailability, non-performance, or other failure by the HOST is the receipt of a Service Credit (if eligible) in accordance with the terms of this SLA. o To receive a Service Credit, CUSTOMER must submit a claim by opening a case in RiskSense® Support link within RiskSense. To be eligible, the credit request must be received by HOST by the end of the second billing cycle after which the incident occurred and must include the following: ■ the words “SLA Credit Request” in the subject line; ■ the dates and times of each Unavailability incident that you are claiming; ■ the CUSTOMER request logs that document the errors and corroborate your claimed outage (any confidential or sensitive information in these logs should be removed or replaced with asterisks). o If the Monthly Uptime Percentage of such request is confirmed by HOST and is less than the Service Commitment, then HOST will issue the Service Credit to CUSTOMER within one billing cycle following the month in which your request is confirmed by us. CUSTOMER’s failure to provide the request and other information as required above will disqualify CUSTOMER from receiving a Service Credit. o Please refer to the EULA for more information on the support process. • Any “Predefined Maintenance Period” is defined as: o Standard Weekly Maintenance - Every Friday evening from 9:00 PM MST to 11:00 PM MST. o Quarterly Maintenance - Once per quarter, the standard weekly maintenance may be extended to up to a maximum duration of 24 hours. Date and time will be scheduled with no less than 120 hours’ notice to the CUSTOMER. o Emergency Maintenance - This is a scheduled maintenance to respond to emergency/security related situations. These will be scheduled with no less than 6 hours advance notice with the CUSTOMER’s approval. o CUSTOMER Requested Maintenance - This is a scheduled maintenance to respond to CUSTOMER specific requests for any reason. Any downtime required here does not count against the Monthly Uptime Percentage. Con-08310 sarf_229438 17 FOR LEGAL USE ONLY CJK

DocuSign Envelope ID: F71FC91B-C1F1-4732-A465-0F932090CAE3 This Master Services Agreement (the “Agreement”) is made between Sales Benchmark Index, having a place of business at 4001 South Decatur, Ste 37-462 Las Vegas, NV 89103 (the “Company”), and Vantiv, LLC having a place of business at 8500 Governors Hill Drive, Symmes Township, OH 45249¬ 1384 for itself and its subsidiaries and Affiliates (collectively “Vantiv”) and shall be effective upon execution by both parties (the “Effective Date”). Company has agreed to make available to Vantiv and Vantiv wishes to purchase and receive the products and services of Company which shall be described in statements of work, therefore, the parties agree as follows: 1. Definitions. The following terms when used in this Agreement will have the meanings set forth in this Section: 1.1. “Affiliate” shall mean any corporation or other business entity that directly or indirectly controls, is controlled by or is under common control with a party. Control means direct or indirect ownership of or other beneficial interest in fifty percent (50%) or more of the voting stock, other vesting interest, or income of a corporation or other business entity. 1.2. “Associations” means Visa, Inc., MasterCard International, Inc., American Express, the Discover Network, ATM/Debit Networks, and other financial service card organizations and any successor organizations. 1.3. "Confidential Information" means nonpublic information, in tangible or intangible form, that a party to this Agreement (“Disclosing Party”) designates as being confidential to the party that receives such information (“Receiving Party”) or which, under the circumstances surrounding disclosure ought to be treated as confidential by Receiving Party. Confidential Information includes, without limitation, know¬ how, trade secrets, technical processes and formulas, software, flow charts, customer lists, pricing information, unpublished financial information, business plans, financial or business projections, marketing data, and information received from others that Disclosing Party is obligated to treat as confidential. Confidential Information shall not include any information, however designated, that: (i) is or subsequently becomes publicly available without Receiving Party's breach of any obligation owed to Disclosing Party; (ii) became known to Receiving Party prior to Disclosing Party's disclosure of such information to Receiving Party pursuant to the terms of this Agreement; (iii) became known to Receiving Party from a source other than Disclosing Party other than by the breach of an obligation of confidentiality; or (iv) is independently developed by Receiving Party. 1.4. “Deliverables” means all items to be delivered to Vantiv pursuant to the terms of this Agreement or a Statement of Work. 1.5. “PCI” means the Payment Card Industry Security Council. 1.6. “PA-DSS” means the then current Payment Application Data Security Standard as promulgated by the PCI. 1.7. “PCI DSS” means the then current Payment Card Industry Data Security Standards as promulgated by the PCI. 1.8. “Rules” means the written regulations and procedures issued by the Associations, as amended from time to time, including but not limited to the rules, regulations, operating procedures, guidelines and requirements as may be promulgated or amended from time to time by the Associations, including but not limited to PCI DSS, Visa Cardholder Information Security Program (“CISP”), MasterCard Site Data Protection (“SDP”) program, and PA-DSS. 1.9. “Services” means the products and services to be provided by the Company to Vantiv under this Agreement. 1.10. “Statement of Work” or “SOW” means the document, which could be a statement of work, quote, order form, schedule, or other name which defines the delivery and/or performance of the Services and/or development of Deliverables that is agreed and subsequently numbered and executed by the parties as further described in Section 4, below. 1.11. "Vantiv Data” means (i) any data or information of Vantiv, its Affiliates, or eligible recipients, or their respective suppliers, customers or other business partners that is provided to or obtained by Company or Company personnel in the performance of its obligations under this Agreement, including data and information regarding Vantiv's Confidential Information, businesses, customers, employees, contractors, operations, equipment, business processes, manufacturing processes, formulas, Vantiv facilities, products, consumer markets, assets and finances, (ii) any data or information created, generated, collected or processed in connection with the Services; and (iii) data or information entered into software, equipment or system by or on behalf of Vantiv, as well as information derived from this information, including any such information as maintained in or processed through any equipment, software or system. 1.12. “Vantiv Secure Data” is a subset of Vantiv Data, including (i) (“Internal Use”) is data such as but not limited to corporate policies, standards, procedures, Corporate policies, standards, procedures, employee lists, job titles, organizational charts, or floor plans; (ii) (“Confidential”) is data such as but not limited to confidential customer information, that is not designated as Restricted, or tied to a person's identity, contract terms, department budgets, marketing and sales plans, pre-public release product information, or (iii) (“Restricted”) is data such as but not limited to access credentials such as passwords, passphrases, and challenge question responses, financial account or payment card numbers, customer information that is tied to a person's identity Legal proceedings, unless publicly available, projected earnings/loss statements, protected health information (“PHI”), social security or tax ID numbers, or gift, debit, or credit card numbers. 1.13. “Work Product” includes, but is not limited to all ideas, concepts, know-how, techniques, inventions, discoveries, developments, innovations, improvements, designs, methods, processes, systems, formulas, compositions of matter, computer programs, software, databases, and original works of authorship made, created, conceived, or first reduced to practice by Company in accordance with this Agreement or SOW whether or not such Work Product may qualify as patents, trademarks, copyrights, trade secrets or other intellectual property. Page 1 of 11 DocuSign Envelope ID: F71FC91B-C1F1-4732-A465-0F932090CAE3 2. Term. 2.1. This Agreement shall commence on the Effective Date and shall continue thereafter for 3 years (“Initial Term”) and unless either party provides notice 90 days prior to the then current term, it shall renew for periods of 1 year (each, a “Renewal Term”), collectively the (“Term”) unless earlier terminated in accordance with this Agreement. 3. Termination. 3.1. For Breach. 3.1.1. Upon 30 days' prior written notice, either party may terminate this Agreement or any Statement of Work hereunder, in whole or in part, for the other Party's breach, provided that such breach has not been cured by the end of such thirty-day period. 3.2. For Insolvency. 3.2.1. Upon notice, either party may terminate this Agreement with immediate effect upon the occurrence of any of the following: (1) the institution by the other party of proceedings to be adjudicated a bankrupt or insolvent; or (2) the consent by the other party to institution of bankruptcy or insolvency proceedings against it; or (3) the filing by the other party of a petition or answer or consent seeking reorganization or release under the Federal Bankruptcy Act, or any other applicable Federal or state law or upon the consent by the other party to the filing of any such petition or the appointment of a receiver, liquidator, assignee, or other similar official; or (4) the making by the other party of an assignment for the benefit of creditors; or (5) upon the admission in writing by the other party of its inability to pay its debts generally as they become due; or (6) if, within 10 days after the commencement of an action against the other party seeking any bankruptcy, insolvency, reorganization, liquidation, dissolution or similar relief under any present or future law or regulation, such action shall not have been dismissed or all orders or proceedings thereunder affecting the operations or the business of the other party stayed, or if the stay of any such order or proceeding shall thereafter be set aside; or (7) if within 10 days after the appointment without the consent or acquiescence of the other party of any trustee, receiver or liquidator or similar official such appointment shall not have been vacated. 3.3. For Convenience. 3.3.1. Vulnerability Management. 8.4.1. At Vantiv's written request, Company shall promptly perform (or shall permit Vantiv or a third party selected by Vantiv to perform) a vulnerability threat assessment ("VTA") test or such additional vulnerability or compromise assessment testing as may be reasonably required by Vantiv. The VTA may be performed, in Vantiv's sole discretion, by either appointed members of Vantiv's information integrity team or a security consultant selected and approved in writing by Vantiv. 8.4.2. If Company has access to Restricted data, then it shall perform quarterly vulnerability assessments of Company's systems used to perform the Services ("Assessments"). Such Assessments shall include an evaluation of Company's externally accessible computer systems from the perspective of an external attacker, with a focus on service discovery and service identification. This assessment shall include a logical assessment, penetration/intrusion testing and/or analysis services. Threats to Company system availability and review of whether attackers could deny legitimate users access to information made available through Company's IT infrastructure may also be evaluated. Such quarterly Assessments shall be at Company's sole expense and shall be conducted by a third party nationally recognized for performing such Assessments (a "VTA Company"), proposed by Company and subject to Vantiv's prior consent, which shall not be unreasonably withheld. 8.4.3. Vantiv may also request that Company have the VTA Company conduct additional Assessments on an ad hoc basis, to provide reviews of Company's infrastructure, applications, networks, internal scans, external scans and code. Such ad hoc Assessments shall be conducted in a manner that does not compromise Company's reasonable security standards applicable to Vantiv, shall be conducted under Company's direction, and shall be at Vantiv's sole expense. Vantiv shall have the right to require Company to use a different VTA Company (other than the one proposed by Company) to perform such additional ad hoc Assessments. 8.4.4. The results of all Assessments described in this section shall be provided by Company to Vantiv and shall include a comprehensive report of the Assessment findings, redacted to exclude only specific information that is confidential and proprietary to Company's other customers. Company and Vantiv shall reach a mutual agreement regarding remediation of the findings within the Assessment results. 8.5. Disaster Recovery Plan. 8.5.1. Company shall immediately notify Vantiv of (a) any actual, attempted or reasonably suspected breach of Company security, its services or systems; (b) any actual, attempted or reasonably suspected unauthorized access to or acquisition, use, loss, destruction, Page 4 of 11 DocuSign Envelope ID: F71FC91B-C1F1-4732-A465-0F932090CAE3 alteration, compromise or disclosure of any NPI, Vantiv Confidential Information, or Vantiv Data, or (c) any circumstance pursuant to which applicable law requires notification of such breach to be given to affected parties or other activity in response to such circumstance (each, a “Security Breach”). 8.6.2. In the event of a Security Breach, Company shall (i) promptly, but in no case more than 1 business days after Company becomes aware of an actual breach or 10 business days of a suspected breach, provide to Vantiv a detailed description of the incident, the data accessed, the identity of individuals or entities involved, if available, and such other information as Vantiv may request concerning the Security Breach; (ii) provide Vantiv with the name and contact information for an employee of Company who shall serve as Company's primary security contact and shall be available to assist Vantiv as a contact in resolving obligations associated with the Security Breach; (iii) assist Vantiv in investigating, remedying and taking any other action Vantiv deems necessary regarding any Security Breach and any dispute, inquiry or claim that concerns the Security Breach; (iv) facilitate interviews with Company's employees and third party service providers, such as computer security or forensic investigation firms assisting in responding to the Security Breach; (v) make available all relevant records, logs, files, report, and analysis regarding the Security Breach, as well as any other materials required to comply with applicable law, regulation, industry standards or as otherwise reasonably required by Vantiv; (vi) shall take prompt actions to ensure that such Security Breach or potential Security Breach will not recur; and (vii) cooperate with Vantiv and any law enforcement or regulatory official investigating such Security Breach. Notwithstanding the foregoing, to the extent not prohibited by applicable law, Vantiv shall make the final decision on notifying Vantiv customers, users, employees, service providers and/or the general public of such Security Breach or any other breach related to security which is not a Security Breach, and the implementation of the remediation plan. If a notification to a Vantiv customer or users is required under any applicable law, guidelines or best practice, then in addition to all other costs arising out of or in connection with such Security Breach, and without prejudice to all other rights and remedies available to Vantiv under this Agreement, at law or in equity, Company shall reimburse Vantiv for all reasonable notification related costs and other expenses incurred by Vantiv arising out of or in connection with any such Security Breach, including but not limited to, credit monitoring services.. 9. Deliverables: • Coaching Charter • Coaching Cadence • Coaching Sessions with Sales Leaders & Sales Managers • Coaching Summary Scorecard Phase 5 Work Breakdown Structure • The following outline details the work that will be done to support the deliverables and the responsible party for each item. 1. Prepare_Owner_ 1.1 Define Coaching Charter 1.1.1 Determine method to baseline and measure behavior change - refer to training SBI certification & gamification results 1.1.2  Define goals of coaching program SBI Page 5 of 8 FOR LEGAL USE ONLY DocuSign Envelope ID: F71FC91B-C1F1-4732-A465-0F932090CAE3 vantiv ADDENDUM - STATEMENT OF WORK 1.1.3 Understand behavior change we are looking for (i.e. - leading indicators that show SBI progress toward goal) 1.1.4 Determine what topics should not be discussed if any (sacred cows?) SBI 1.1.5 Populate coaching charter and send to Executive Sponsor for validation SBI 1.2 Identify Coaching Relationships 1.2.1 Determine coaching time allocation between A, B and C players. Shared 1.2.2 Match SBI coaches to players (Considerations: Tenure, level of experience, optics, Shared subject matter expertise, personal fit, geography) 1.2.3 Document coaching relationship and any risks or considerations identified SBI 1.2.4 Determine coaching activities to deploy (Virtual coaching, Face-to-Face observation of SBI behavior, DILO/Job Shadowing, Tell them, show them, watch them, retrain, manage) 1.3 Establish Cadence 1.3.1 Establish performance threshold for coaching program by participant Shared
1.3.2 Agree on time per interaction SBI
1.3.3 Agree on interaction type(s) (i.e.-Virtual vs. Face to Face) SBI
1.3.4 Determine technology usage - GTM, video, telephone only? SBI
1.3.5 1.4 Communicate Document coaching cadence by participant and validate with Vantiv: SBI
1.4.1 Determine communication channel (s) SBI
1.4.2 Develop ghost communication to be sent by Vantiv to (Player, Player’s boss, any other SBI
stakeholders)
1.4.3 Agree on timing for communication to ensure coaching program is initiated on time SBI
1.4.4 Communicate baselines for behaviors we are looking to change with the program SBI
1.4.5 Prepare for resistance - discuss common forms of coaching resistance Shared
1.4.6 Send communication to all coaching participants with program expectations Vantiv
1.4.7 Discuss internal communication between coaches SBI
1.4.8 Determine how to enable Online collaboration (e.g. Chatter) SBI
1.4.9 Discuss ongoing project communication and decision making process with Executive SBI
Sponsor
2. Coach Owner
2.1 Create Guides 2.1.1 Create a PRE-Interaction reminders for the coaches to include Coaching Program Charter, Coaching Prep Form, Performance info, Development info SBI
2.1.2 Create a Coaching Prep Guide to include how to Interview current manager, past managers, and peers; Obtain comp plan and past 3 year performance history; Study LinkedIn profile to understand past experience SBI
2.1.3 Create a Coaching Execution Guide to include building rapport, determining their coaching objectives, their learning preferences, the SMART approach, and Adding value immediately SBI
2.1.4 Create a Coaching Follow-up Guide to include immediate post call response, tracking mechanism, mid-course corrections, and obtaining feedback SBI
2.1.5 Modify each Coaching Guidance based on Vantiv feedback SBI
2.2 Conduct Coaching Interactions
2.2.1 Schedule recurring interactions SBI
2.2.2 Conduct the Coaching interactions (n = xxx interactions of xxx type over xxx timeframe) SBI
2.2.3 Implement one-on-one remediation actions (e.g. Send content related to area of development, Provide best practices, Connect them with others that perform the skill well, show them how to perform the task or demonstrate the skill, role play) SBI
2.2.4 Collect evidence of each coaching interaction and the results of the coaching over time SBI
Acceptance Criteria for Phase 5 Coaching: Upon receipt via email of either a document or summary of activities completed for each deliverable outlined below, Vantiv has 72 business hours.to review and approve the deliverables via email, after 72 such business hours SBI may assume approval in order to avoid project delays. • Coaching Charter defined, with goals defined, with approval by Vantiv leadership. • Coaching relationships identified, with coaching activities determined for each relationship, with approval by Vantiv leadership. • Coaching Cadence established (i.e. performance threshold for coaching program by participant determined, agreed on interaction types) and documented by participant and validated, with approval by Vantiv leadership. Page 6 of 8 DocuSign Envelope ID: F71FC91B-C1F1-4732-A465-0F932090CAE3 vantiv ADDENDUM - STATEMENT OF WORK • Coaching communication plans developed, including communication channel(s), ghost communications, timing of plan roll out, approved by Vantiv leadership. • Coaching guides created to include: PRE-Interaction reminders for the coaches, Coaching Prep Guide, Coaching Execution Guide, Coaching Follow-up Guide, all approved by Vantiv leadership. • Recurring Coaching interactions scheduled with an agreed upon iteration, one-on-one remediation plans implemented and evidence collected of each coaching interaction, with the results of the coaching over time, all approved by Vantiv leadership. 3. Project Resource(s), Roles and Responsibilities: Company will provide resource(s) capable of fulfilling the responsibilities as outlined in the following section. Assuming this SOW is signed by Vantiv by 6/5/15 and the project kicks off by 6-11-15. Consultant John Staples - [Partner, responsible for the projects overall deliverables and schedule, provides experience to the engagement by providing executive level guidance and industry best practices. Collaborates directly with client senior executive team and steering committee. ] Consultant Scott Gruher - [Partner, Administers SBI's AgiliTrust delivery methodology where results are refined real-time based upon the work of the engagement team. Enables the engagement team to meet all deadlines as communicated to the client sponsor. Assures consistent quality of SBI's final product so it will be implemented and utilized as designed. ] Consultant Andrew Urteaga - [Principal, Provides experience to the engagement by combining executive-level know-how, industry best¬ practices, and intimate knowledge of client objectives. Collaborates directly with the client's senior executives, project sponsor, and client-appointed steering committee. Continually refines the strategic direction of the engagement based on client and SBI team input. ] Consultant Joel McCabe [Senior Consultant, Immerses into the client's organization to gain a comprehensive understanding of the problems and symptoms. Becomes a part of the organization while providing ongoing insights and solution designs. Leads working level meetings, presents solutions, provides training and coaching as needed. 4. Cost: The investment required to accomplish the work outlined in this Statement of work is a fixed fee of $225,000 The invoicing schedule is as follows: • 30% Due upon SOW signature • 30% Due by day 30 • 30% Due by day 60 • 10% Due 15 days following conclusion of project delivery The project fee does not include travel or other production expenses not to exceed 10%, or a total project cost of $247,500 without prior written authorization by Vantiv. These expenses will be billed as incurred and reimbursed by Client. This agreement, may be delayed without penalty provided the revised start date is within 90 days of the Execution Date of this sow. 5. Start Date / End Date: 12 weeks Start Date:6/17/2015 End Date: 9/10/2015 Further extension - upon agreement 6. The parties acknowledge and agree that the end date above is an estimate. Termination - The parties expressly agree this SOW takes control over the Addendum and/or the Agreement with regard to Termination: Either party may terminate this Statement of Work hereunder, in whole or in part, with or without cause upon 30 days' prior written notice to other party. If this Statement of Work is terminated without cause by Vantiv, in addition to compensating SBI through the 30 day notice period, Vantiv will also make a onetime termination payment equal to 50% of the remaining fees due under this SOW Signatures: This Statement of Work may be signed in counterparts, each of which shall be deemed an original. By signing below the parties represent and warrant that the signing authority below has the legal authority to bind their organization to the terms of the Agreement. IN WITNESS WHEREOF, the parties have caused this Statement of Work to be executed by their duly authorized representatives as identified below. Vantiv, LLC # DocuSigned by: Mam^69683C46F64B3... DocuSign Envelope ID: 2C5F1C12-6AEE-4DE4-8AE7-26E1FA3FB524 THIS FRAMEWORK SERVICES AGREEMENT is made on 13 November 2018 (the "Effective Date”) BETWEEN: (1) WORLDPAY (UK) LIMITED, a company incorporated in England with registered number 07316500, whose registered office is at The Walbrook Building, 25 Walbrook, London, EC4N 8AF ("Worldpay”); and (2) SalesOptimize Limited a company incorporated in Ireland with registered number 535631 whose registered office is at Garadice House,3-4 Fairview, Dublin 3. (the "Supplier”). WHEREAS: (A) The Worldpay Group is a leading global payment processor and wishes to engage the Supplier to provide certain Services (as defined below). (B) The Supplier has represented that it has specialist skill and expertise in relation to the provision of the Services of the type and nature required by Worldpay and its Group. (C) The Supplier has agreed to provide the Services to Worldpay and its Group on the terms and conditions of this Agreement and each SOW. IT IS AGREED AS FOLLOWS: 1. INTERPRETATION 1.1 In this Agreement, unless the context otherwise requires, the following expressions have the following meanings: Acceptance: has the meaning set out in clause 3.6 and "Accepted” shall be construed accordingly; Acceptance Criteria: means the (test) criteria that a Deliverable must meet in order for it to be Accepted, as set out in an SOW; Affected Employee: has the meaning set out in clause 17.3; Affected Party: has the meaning set out in clause 16.5; Agreement: means this Agreement, its schedules, appendices, annexes and any other document incorporated by reference that is signed by the authorised representatives of the parties and expressed to be part of the Agreement; Business Day(s): means any day from Monday to Friday on which banks are open for business in Worldpay's local jurisdiction; Cardholder Data: means information relating to a cardholder including, but not limited to, credit card numbers, transactional information and any other Personal Data relating to such cardholder; Charges: means the fees payable by Worldpay to the Supplier for the provision of the Services, as set out in each SOW; Commercially Reasonable Efforts: means that the Party obliged to perform shall take all such steps to perform in such a manner as if it were acting in a determined, prudent and reasonable manner in order to achieve the desired result for its own benefit; Completion Date: the date specified in the Implementation Plan or an SOW by which the Services are to be completed and all the Deliverables Accepted; Confidential Information: means the existence and contents of this Agreement and any SOW, any data (including Personal Data and other Worldpay Data) and all secret and/or confidential, commercial, financial, marketing, technical, know-how, trade secrets, employee or other information relating to the Supplier or Worldpay in any form or medium whether disclosed orally, or in writing, before or after the date of this Agreement, together with any reproductions of such information in any form or medium, or any part of such information disclosed by either Party to the other pursuant to this Agreement, including information clearly labelled as such or identified as Confidential Information and any other information that by its nature is confidential; Contract Year: means each twelve (12) month period during the Term, commencing on the Effective Date; Control: means in respect of a Party, the exercise or ability to exercise or entitlement to acquire, direct or indirect control over such Party by means of ownership, contract or otherwise; SARF_278435 CON-11563 For Legal Use Only M.A.L. DocuSign Envelope ID: 2C5F1C12-6AEE-4DE4-8AE7-26E1FA3FB524 Delay Payments: means a stipulated sum, as set out in an SOW, payable by the Supplier to Worldpay for the failure to provide the Deliverables by the applicable Milestone Date; Deliverables: means outputs (including Software and/or Documentation) the Supplier provides as part of the Services, as set out in an SOW; Disabling Device: means any virus, built-in or use-driven destruction mechanism, software program or code intended to destroy, interfere with, corrupt, or cause undesired effects on program files, data or other information, executable code or application software macros, whether or not its operation is immediate or delayed; Documentation: means any document, methodology or process, data or other material relating to the Services, including, any reports, specifications, business rules or requirements, user manuals, user guides, operations manuals, training materials and instructions; Employee Liabilities: mean all claims (whether in tort, contract or statute or otherwise), demands, actions, proceedings and any award, compensation, damages, tribunal awards, fine, loss, order, penalty, disbursement, payment made by way of settlement and costs and expenses reasonably incurred in connection with a claim or investigation, including any legal costs and expenses, incurred in connection with any Personnel, Affected Employee or other employee; Force Majeure Event: means an event whose occurrence is beyond a Party's reasonable control but which shall exclude any dispute relating to the Supplier or the Personnel or any other failure in the Supplier's or a sub-contractor's supply chain; Good Industry Practice: means, in relation to any undertaking and any circumstances, the exercise of that degree of professionalism, skill, diligence, prudence and foresight which would reasonably and ordinarily be expected from a skilled and experienced person engaged in the same type of activity under the same or similar circumstances required to match the practices and professional standards of best practice organisations; Group/Group Company: means Worldpay and any holding company of Worldpay and any subsidiary of such holding company from time to time that directly or indirectly through one or more intermediaries Controls, or is Controlled by, or is under Control with Worldpay; Implementation Plan: means the timetable for the delivery of the Services and the Deliverables, together with the applicable Milestones as set out in or attached to each SOW; Insolvency Event: means in relation to either Party: (a) the Party becomes unable to pay its debts as they fall due, or the value of the Party's assets is less than the amount of its liabilities, taking into account its contingent and prospective liabilities; (b) a petition is presented, an order made or a resolution passed for the Party's liquidation (other than for a solvent amalgamation or reconstruction), administration, bankruptcy or dissolution; (c) an administrative or other receiver, manager, trustee, liquidator, administrator or similar person or officer is appointed to the Party and/or over all or any part of the Party's assets; (d) the Party enters into or proposes any composition or arrangement concerning its debts with its creditors (or any class of its creditors) generally; or (e) anything equivalent to any of the events or circumstances stated in (a) to (d) inclusive occurs in any applicable jurisdiction; Intellectual Property Rights: means: (a) patents, inventions, designs, copyright and related rights, database rights, trade marks and related goodwill, trade names (whether registered or unregistered), know-how, trade secrets and rights to apply for registration; (b) proprietary rights in domain names; (c) applications, extensions and renewals in relation to any of these rights; and (d) all other rights of a similar nature or having an equivalent effect anywhere in the world; Key Personnel: means a list of Personnel who are essential for the performance of the Services, as set out in an SOW; Law: means all laws and regulations in force and applicable to a Party in respect of its rights and obligations under this Agreement, including any order of a court of competent jurisdiction and the rules or directions of any Regulatory Authority; DocuSign Envelope ID: 2C5F1C12-6AEE-4DE4-8AE7-26E1FA3FB524 SCHEDULE 5 - SUPPLIER CODE OF CONDUCT Introduction At Worldpay, we hold ourselves to high business standards and we want to work with suppliers who do the same. We work smart, we're spirited and we're supportive, and these values are evident in all we do. That's why we promote high legal, ethical, corporate and employee-related standards in our own business and ask our suppliers to do the same. We realise you will have values of your own. Not all statements below are contractually binding, but we hope that our respective values and standards will be compatible so we can do great work together. We are seeking your commitment to work with us to the spirit of the standards set out below. In our interaction with each other Integrity We'll always be honest and fair with each other. Clarity Our communications will be clear, unambiguous and timely. We'll keep to the facts. Feedback We can be open in our feedback to each other and learn from each other's good practices. We'll talk at appropriate intervals when things are going well, and talk more often when they're not. Value-focus We try to continuously improve the value of our services. We'll work together to identify and communicate opportunities to innovate, improve efficiency and avoid waste. Assets We'll respect and protect each other's physical and intellectual assets as if they were our own. Health and safety We'll protect the physical safety of our colleagues and minimise their exposure to health risks. Respect We will respect each person's right to their opinion. There will be no harassment or bullying behaviours. Exchange of trade We won't buy products or services based solely on a reciprocal arrangement nor do we promise or threaten to leverage existing or potential business in order to gain preferential treatment. In our dealings with the wider world Bribery and corruption We won't take advantage of others through manipulation, concealment, abuse of confidential information, misrepresentation of facts or other unfair business practises and all our staff complete training in this area to ensure they understand appropriate behaviours. Bribery and corruption won't be tolerated. Corporate responsibility We'll act in a socially responsible manner appropriate to the countries where we operate. We'll seek to protect and sustain our environment, and to support local charities, community groups and initiatives that have an ambition to improve life in the communities in which we work. Diversity and inclusion We strive for our culture and ways of working to be fully inclusive. We will engage, promote and manage our people's performance based on merit and we won't tolerate discrimination on any grounds. Human rights We will respect all internationally proclaimed human rights. Child labour We won't engage in or support child labour. We will employ only workers who meet the minimum legal age requirement for their country. We look forward to working with you. Thank you. Signed on behalf of: Worldpay Print Name: Philip Jansen

Date: 15th October 2018 Signature: Date: 15th October 2018 Signature: For Legal Use Only M.A.L. DocuSign Envelope ID: 2C5F1C12-6AEE-4DE4-8AE7-26E1FA3FB524 SCHEDULE 6 INFORMATION SECURITY REQUIREMENTS 1. The Supplier will implement and operate: (a) up to date anti-virus software; (b) a patch management process, which ensures patches are appropriately tested and deployed to rectify security vulnerabilities in a reasonable timeframe; (c) robust processes to ensure that access to Worldpay Data under its control is restricted to those individuals whom are explicitly authorised to access such data. Access shall be limited to those with a business need for such access and to those privileges needed to fulfil that need only. Access shall be assigned using unique logon credentials to ensure accountability is maintained; (d) strong authentication methods (two-factor authentication) for those of its Personnel who work remotely and for those with administrative privileges upon systems used to provide the Deliverables or Services; (e) mechanisms to prevent the unauthorised removal of Worldpay Data from the Supplier's networks via technologies such as removable media devices, the internet, email or instant messaging services; (f) encryption technologies to protect Worldpay Data during transmission and storage; (g) encryption technologies upon portable devices such as laptops, PDAs and smartphones; (h) physical and logical controls to mitigate the risk of unauthorised intrusion to Supplier's premises, networks and systems; (i) systems and software development processes to ensure that commonly known security flaws (such as those defined by the Open Web Application Security Project) are not introduced into systems used to supply the Deliverables and the Services; (j) separate environments between test and production systems and will ensure that no production data of Worldpay is used in test systems; (k) robust processes to ensure that changes to the premises, networks, systems and software used to supply the Deliverables and the Services are appropriately tested and implemented to limit the potential of service degradation; and (l) processes to continually monitor its networks and systems for potential or actual security breaches. 2. Where all, or part of, the Deliverables are provided using online services (i.e. accessible via the internet), the Supplier must ensure that adequate protection is in place to mitigate the risk of denial-of-service (DoS) threats. 3. The Supplier shall ensure that processes employed in the provision of the Deliverables are staffed in such manner as to prevent conflicts of interest, fraud or error by invoking appropriate separation of duties. SARF_278435 CON-11563 DocuSign Envelope ID: 2C5F1C12-6AEE-4DE4-8AE7-26E1FA3FB524 SCHEDULE 7 SAFEGUARDING DATA PART A: PERSONAL DATA 1. In this Schedule, the following terms have the following meanings: Data Controller: has the meaning given to that term in the Data Protection Act 1998; Data Processor: has the meaning given to that term in the Data Protection Act 1998; Data Protection Legislation: means the provisions of applicable Law which relate to the protection of individuals with regards to the Processing of Personal Data to which a Party is subject, including without limitation the Data Protection Act 1998, the Data Protection Directive 95/46/EC, the Regulation of Investigatory Powers Act 2000, the Telecommunications (Lawful Business Practice (Interception of Communications) Regulation 2000, the Electronic Communications Data Protection Directive 2002/58/EC, the Privacy and Electronic Communications (EC Directive) Regulations 2003, and in each case any regulations thereunder and, where applicable, the guidance, directions and codes of practice of the UK Information Commissioner's Office and of any other competent privacy Regulatory Authority. Reference to the Data Protection Act 1998 shall, as from 25th May 2018 be replaced by references to the General Data Protection Regulation ((EU) 2016/679); Data Subject: has the meaning given to that term in the Data Protection Act 1998; Personal Data: has the meaning given to that term in the Data Protection Act 1998; and Processing: has the meaning given to that term in the Data Protection Act 1998. 2. In accordance with the provisions of clause 10, if the Supplier has access to any Personal Data, then the provisions of Part A of this Schedule shall apply. All such Personal Data shall be and remain the property of Worldpay. Unless otherwise required by Law, the Supplier shall, as soon as reasonably practicable, return or if Worldpay so elects, destroy (and in the case of destruction, certify that such destruction has taken place), all Personal Data upon any of the following: (a) at Worldpay's request; (b) the termination or expiration of this Agreement or the relevant SOW; or (c) when the Personal Data is no longer required by the Supplier for the provision of the Services. 3. The Supplier shall comply at all times with the Data Protection Legislation and shall not perform any of its obligations under this Agreement or any SOW in such a way as to cause Worldpay to breach any of its applicable obligations under the relevant Data Protection Legislation. 4. The Supplier shall not use any Worldpay Data for any purpose other than the rendering of Services to Worldpay and shall not disclose the Worldpay Data to any third parties or commercially exploit the Worldpay Data. The Supplier shall and shall procure that its Personnel shall not attempt to access or allow access to Worldpay Data to which they are not entitled or that is not required for the performance of the Services. 5. To the extent that the Supplier processes any Personal Data on behalf of Worldpay, the Supplier acknowledges that it is the Data Processor in relation to such data and shall procure that its Personnel shall: (a) obtain prior written consent from Worldpay in order to transfer the Personal Data to any sub-contractors or third parties for the provision of the Services; SARF_278435 CON-11563 DocuSign Envelope ID: 2C5F1C12-6AEE-4DE4-8AE7-26E1FA3FB524 (b) Process the Personal Data strictly in accordance with instructions from Worldpay or the terms of this Agreement and then only to the extent, and in such manner, as is necessary for the provision of the Services, or as is required by Law or any Regulatory Authority; (c) ensure that only the Personnel shall have access to the Personal Data and that all such Personnel have undergone training in the Data Protection Legislation and in the care and handling of Personal Data and are under an appropriate duty of confidentiality at least equivalent to those set out in clause 9; (d) implement appropriate technical and organisational measures to safeguard against unauthorised Processing (including accidental or unlawful destruction, loss, unauthorised disclosure of, or access to or alteration of, Personal Data transmitted, stored or otherwise Processed); (e) not process Personal Data in a public place or any location where such Personal Data may be viewed by others, including in waiting areas, on public transport or across unencrypted public networks; (f) promptly refer to Worldpay (and at the latest within two (2) Business Days) any queries relating to Personal Data Processed on behalf of Worldpay from Data Subjects, any information commissioner or any other Regulatory Authority, which Worldpay may decide to resolve at its discretion, and at no additional cost, promptly provide such information to Worldpay as Worldpay may reasonably require to allow it to comply with the rights of the Data Subjects, including subject access rights, or information notices or queries requested by a Regulatory Authority; (g) promptly carry out any request from Worldpay requiring the Supplier to amend, transfer or delete the Personal Data or any part of the Personal Data; (h) provide to Worldpay on request such information as may be reasonably requested by Worldpay regarding the steps the Supplier has taken to comply with its obligations under this Schedule 7 Part A and the Data Protection Legislation including, without prejudice to Worldpay's rights under clause 6, submitting to audits, including inspections, conducted by Worldpay or a third party auditor mandated by Worldpay; (i) immediately inform Worldpay if, in the Supplier's opinion, a Worldpay instruction infringes the Data Protection Legislation; (j) not process or otherwise transfer any Personal Data outside the European Economic Area without Worldpay's express prior written consent and if such consent is provided, shall only process or otherwise transfer such Personal Data on terms that comply with applicable Data Protection Legislation (insofar as it relates to Worldpay as Data Controller), including without limitation the eighth data protection principle set out in the Data Protection Act 1998; and (k) maintain all such records of its processing activity as are required of it as a Data Processor acting in accordance with the Data Protection Legislation and on request of Worldpay, make such records available to any Regulatory Authority. 6. Without prejudice to paragraphs 5(a) and 5(i) above, or clause 19.10, where the Supplier wishes to appoint a subcontractor who shall process the Personal Data, the Supplier shall contract with such subcontractor on terms which are the same as or substantively similar to, and no less onerous than, the terms set out in this Agreement in connection with Personal Data and as if the subcontractor were the Supplier, which shall name Worldpay as a third party beneficiary giving Worldpay directly enforceable rights under such agreement and terminate automatically upon the Supplier ceasing to process such Personal Data. 7. The Supplier acknowledges that any consent to a subcontractor provided by Worldpay may be withdrawn by Worldpay if and to the extent that Worldpay reasonable believes that the Personal Data or the rights of the Data Subjects may be compromised by the relevant subcontractor. Any subcontractor approved by Worldpay under this Agreement shall not be entitled to, and the Supplier shall ensure that they do not appoint, any further third party or SARF_278435 CON-11563 e^onlv DocuSign Envelope ID: 2C5F1C12-6AEE-4DE4-8AE7-26E1FA3FB524 subprocessor, other than with the consent of Worldpay and pursuant to the terms of Part A of this Schedule. 8. The Supplier shall immediately notify Worldpay upon becoming aware of a breach in respect of any Personal Data Processed by or under the control of the Supplier and shall on an ongoing basis provide Worldpay with all such further relevant information in connection with the breach as such information becomes available so as to enable Worldpay to determine whether to notify the breach to the applicable Regulatory Authority and Data Subjects. Such notification shall at a minimum: (a) describe the nature of the Personal Data breach including where possible, the categories and approximate number of Data Subjects concerned and the categories and approximate number of Personal Data records concerned; (b) the name and contact details of the Data Protection Officer or other contact point where more information can be obtained; (c) the likely consequences of the Personal Data breach; and (d) the measures taken or proposed to be taken by the Supplier to address the Personal Data breach, including, where appropriate, measures to mitigate its possible adverse effects. 9. The Supplier shall indemnify Worldpay, its Group Companies, officers and/or directors against all Losses suffered or incurred by Worldpay, its Group Companies, officers and/or directors arising out of or in connection with the Supplier's breach of Part A of this Schedule. SARF_278435 CON-11563 DocuSign Envelope ID: 2C5F1C12-6AEE-4DE4-8AE7-26E1FA3FB524 PART B: CARDHOLDER DATA 1. If the Supplier has any access to Cardholder Data, any environment storing, processing, or transmitting Cardholder Data, or can affect the security of Cardholder Data or a Cardholder Data environment, Part B of this Schedule shall apply. 2. The Supplier will maintain full compliance with the current version of the standards of the Payment Card Industry Security Standards Council (including Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard ("PCI DSS”), the Payment Application Data Security Standard and the PIN Transaction Security Standard) and any other applicable payment card data security standards, as each may be modified from time to time (the "PCI Standards”), at its own cost throughout the term of the relevant SOW. 3. The Supplier acknowledges that it is responsible for the security of Cardholder Data which the Supplier and its Personnel possess or otherwise store, process or transmit on behalf of Worldpay and/or its Worldpays, including to the extent that the Supplier's acts or omissions could impact the security of the environment or systems used by Worldpay (or its Worldpays) to store, process or transmit Cardholder Data. 4. The Supplier will appoint a qualified security assessor ("QSA”) to verify its compliance with the PCI Standards as a Level 1 Service Provider, and obtain a PCI DSS Report on Compliance ("ROC”). 5. The Supplier will provide evidence of its compliance with the PCI Standards annually and as Worldpay reasonably requests from time to time by: (a) providing Worldpay with an Attestation of Compliance ("AOC”) signed both by the Supplier and the QSA and dated within the prior twelve (12) months; (b) providing Worldpay with a copy of the executive summary from the latest ROC from the QSA or a letter of attestation, describing the scope and services assessed by the QSA; and (c) providing to Worldpay in writing details of its procedures and policies relating to and implementing compliance with the PCI Standards. 6. The Supplier shall indemnify Worldpay, its Group Companies, officers and/or directors against all Losses suffered or incurred by Worldpay, its Group Companies, officers and/or directors arising out of or in connection with the Supplier's breach of Part B of this Schedule or any failure to comply with the PCI Standards and/or any incident of loss or compromise of Cardholder Data attributable to the Supplier or its Personnel. SARF_278435 CON-11563 For Legal Use Only M.A.L. DocuSign Envelope ID: 2C5F1C12-6AEE-4DE4-8AE7-26E1FA3FB524 SCHEDULE 8 AMENDMENTS TO THE AGREEMENT WHEN WORLDPAY US, INC. IS A PARTY TO THE APPLICABLE SOW If the Group Company is Worldpay US, Inc., the following amendments shall take effect solely with respect to the applicable SOW(s) between Worldpay US, Inc. and Supplier and upon execution of the applicable SOW: a. Where the Supplier is solely processing the Personal Data of individuals located in the USA, the definition of "Personal Data” shall be replaced with: "names, addresses, birth-dates, demographic information, driver's license numbers, social security numbers, telephone numbers, account numbers, account and transaction information, Worldpay lists and pricing information and any other "Non-Public Information” as defined in the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act, 15 U.S.C. 6801 et seq. Where the Supplier undertaking the data processing, or the individuals whose Personal Data is being processed, are based in the European Union, the definition shall remain unamended. b. Clause 5.4 shall be deleted and replaced with the following: "5.4 Each invoice shall reference this Agreement and the applicable Worldpay purchase order number or such invoice may be rejected by Worldpay in its sole discretion. Invoices shall be sent directly to Worldpay Accounts Payable either by mail to Worldpay Accounts Payable, 201 17th Street NW, Suite 1000, Atlanta, Georgia 30363 or by e-mail to WPAccountsPayable@Worldpay.us. Worldpay shall pay the Charges within 60 days of receipt of the applicable invoice. All Charges shall be calculated and payments made in U.S. Dollars unless otherwise set out in a Statement of Work.” c. Clause 11.1 shall be amended by the addition of the following at the end of the Clause: "The Supplier shall in addition ensure that it operates in compliance with ISO 27001 and ISO 27002 (or any replacement standard relating to information security).On at least an annual basis, Supplier shall (i) review and update, as applicable, its policies and procedures with respect to safekeeping of Worldpay's Confidential Information, and (ii) provide Worldpay with such policies and procedures upon Worldpay's request. The covenants, rights and obligations set forth in this Clause 11 will survive for a period of three years following the termination of this Agreement; provided, however, that with respect to any Confidential Information that constitutes a trade secret under applicable law, the obligations of this Agreement shall survive for the longer of three years or so long as such information remains a trade secret (as such term is defined in the Georgia Trade Secrets Act (O.C.G.A. §10-1-760 et. seq.), as amended, or applicable law), excluding failure to so qualify as a result of breach of this Agreement.” d. Clauses 14.5 and 14.6 shall be deleted and replaced with the following: "14.5 Supplier shall maintain during the term of this Agreement the following insurance ("Required Insurance”): 14.5.1 Worker's Compensation and employers' liability insurance as prescribed by applicable law; 14.5.2 Commercial general liability insurance (bodily injury, product liability and property damage) with contractual liability insurance to cover liability assumed under this Agreement and the limits of such insurance shall not be less than $10,000,000 per occurrence and $20,000,000 annual aggregate; 14.5.3 Automobile bodily injury and property damage liability insurance covering owned, non¬ owned and hired automobiles, the limit of which shall not be less than $1,000,000 per occurrence; 14.5.4 Errors and omissions Insurance, the limits of liability of which shall not be less than $5,000,000 per each occurrence and $10,000,000 annual aggregate; and SARF_278435 CON-11563 For Legal Use Only M.A.L. DocuSign Envelope ID: 2C5F1C12-6AEE-4DE4-8AE7-26E1FA3FB524 14.5.5 Data breach insurance to cover liability assumed under this Agreement and the limits of such insurance shall not be less than $10,000,000 per occurrence and $20,000,000 annual aggregate. 14.6 Supplier shall deliver promptly to Worldpay certificates of insurance made out by the applicable insurer(s) or their authorized agents for the insurance required under this clause and for any material policy amendments thereto. Each policy shall provide for 30 days prior written notice to be given by insurer to Worldpay in the event of any termination, non-renewal or cancellation or any material change in coverage or deductibles. Supplier, Supplier's insurer(s) and anyone claiming by, through, under or on Supplier's behalf shall have no claim, right of action or right of subrogation against Worldpay or its Worldpays based on any loss or liability insured under the Required Insurance. All Required Insurance shall be carried with Reputable Insurance Companies which are authorized to do business in the state in which the Services are rendered. Supplier acknowledges and agrees that its insurance policies and insurer shall pay Worldpay in U.S. Dollars in the event of a claim in respect of the performance by Supplier of the Services hereunder. In no event shall Clauses 14.5 or 14.6 limit Supplier's liability under this Agreement." e. Clause 17 ("TUPE") shall be deleted and replaced with "17. Not Applicable." f. Clause 19.6 is hereby amended to add the following to the end of the clause: "For purposes of clause 19.6, notices to Worldpay US, Inc. shall be sent to 201 17th Street, NW, Suite 1000, Atlanta, GA 30363, Attention: Legal Department." g. Clause 19.6(iv) is hereby amended by the insertion of the words "(designated, in the case of Worldpay, by the Worldpay legal department)" after the words "sent by email". h. Clauses 21.1 and 21.2 shall be deleted and replaced with: "21.1 The terms of this Agreement shall be governed by and construed in accordance with the laws of the State of Georgia without resort to conflict of laws rules. 21.2 Each Party irrevocably agrees that any action, suit or other legal proceeding against them shall be brought in a court of the State of Georgia or in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Georgia. By execution and delivery of this Agreement, each Party irrevocably submits to and accepts such jurisdiction and waives any objection (including any objection to venue, enforcement, or grounds of forum non conveniens) that might be asserted against the bringing of any such action, suit or other legal proceeding in such court." SARF_278435 CON-11563 For Legal Use Only M.A.L.

THIS FRAMEWORK SERVICES AGREEMENT is made on 17-4- 2016 BETWEEN: (1) WORLDPAY (UK) LIMITED, a company incorporated in England with registered number 07316500, whose registered office is at The Walbrook Building, 25 Walbrook, London, EC4N 8AF ("Worldpay"); and (2) SAMEN LEF! B.V. a company incorporated in The Netherlands with registered number 61195952 whose registered office is at van Geiderlaan 45, 1215SM, Hilversum (the "Supplier"). WHEREAS: (A) The Woridpay Group Is a leading global payment processor and wishes to engage the Supplier to provide certain Services (as defined below). (B) The Supplier has represented that it has specialist skill and expertise in relation to the provision of the Services of the type and nature required by Worldpay and its Group. (C) The Supplier has agreed to provide the Services to Worldpay and its Group on the terms and conditions of this Agreement and each Statement of Work. IT IS AGREED AS FOLLOWS: 1. INTERPRETATION 1.1 In this Agreement, unless the context otherwise requires, the following expressions have the following meanings: Acceptance: has the meaning set out in clause 3.7 and "Accepted" shall be construed accordingly; Acceptance Criteria: means the criteria that a Deliverable must meet in order for it to be Accepted, which may include Acceptance Test Criteria, as set out In a Statement of Work; Acceptance Date: has the meaning set out In clause 3.7; Acceptance Test: means, where applicable, the tests to be performed by the Supplier to achieve Acceptance, as set out in a Statement of Work and "Testing" shall be construed accordingly; Acceptance Test Criteria: means the criteria set out in a Statement of Work which must be met during Testing In order for the relevant Deliverable to be Accepted; Affected Employee: has the meaning set out in clause 18.3; Affected Party: has the meaning set out in clause 17.5; Agreement: means this Agreement, its schedules, appendices, annexes and any other document incorporated by reference that is signed by the authorised representatives of the parties and expressed to be part of the Agreement; Business Day(s): means any day from Monday to Friday on which banks are open for business in England; Cardholder Data: means information relating to, a cardholder including, but not limited to, credit card numbers, transactional information and any other Personal Data relating to such cardholder; Charges: means the fees payable by Worldpay (or a Group Company) to the Supplier for the provision of the Services, as set out in each Statement of Work; Completion Date: the date specified In the Implementation Plan or a Statement of Work by which the Services are to be completed and all the Deliverables Accepted; Confidential Information: means the existence and contents of this Agreement and any Statement of Work, any data (including Personal Data) and all secret and or confidential, commercial, financial, marketing, technical, know-how, trade secrets, employee or other information relating to the Supplier or Worldpay in any form or medium whether disclosed orally, or in writing, before or after the date of this Agreement, together with any reproductions of such information In any form or medium, or any part of such information disclosed by either Party to the other pursuant to this Agreement, including information clearly labelled as such or identified as Confidential Information and any other information that by its nature is confidential; Contract Year: means each 12 month period during the Term, commencing on the Effective Date; V3 Page i of 30 Control: means in respect of a Party, the exercise or ability to exercise or entitlement to acquire, direct or indirect control over such Party by means of ownership, contract or otherwise; Data Controller: has the meaning given to that term in the Data Protection Act 1998; Data Processor: has the meaning given to that term In the Data Protection Act 1998; Data Protection Legislation: means the provisions of applicable Law which relate to the protection of individuals with regards to the Processing of Personal Data to which a Party is subject, including without limitation the Data Protection Act 1998, the Data Protection Directive 95/46/EC, the Regulation of Investigatory Powers Act 2000, the Telecommunications (Lawful Business Practice (Interception of Communications) Regulation 2000, the Electronic Communications Data Protection Directive 2002/58/EC, the Privacy and Electronic Communications (EC Directive) Regulations 2003 and, where applicable, the guidance and code of practice issued by the Information Commissioner's Office from time to time, directions of any competent privacy Regulatory Authority, relevant regulatory guidance and codes of practice; Data Subject: has the meaning given to that term In the Data Protection Act 1998; Delay Payments: means a stipulated sum, as set out in a Statement of Work, payable by the Supplier to Worldpay for the failure to provide the Deliverables by the applicable Milestone Date; Deliverables: means outputs (including Software or software configuration set ups) or Materials the Supplier provides as part of the Services, as set out in a Statement of Work; Employee Liabilities: mean all claims (whether in tort, contract or statute or otherwise), demands, actions, proceedings and any award, compensation, damages, tribunal awards, fine, loss, order, penalty, disbursement, payment made by way of settlement and costs and expenses reasonably incurred in connection with a claim or investigation, including any legal costs and expenses, incurred in connection with any Personnel, Affected Employee or other employee; Effective Date: means the date of this Agreement; FCA: means the Financial Conduct Authority of the United Kingdom; Force Majeure Event: means an event, the occurrence of which is beyond the reasonable control of a Party; Good Industry Practice: means, in relation to any undertaking and any circumstances, the exercise of that degree of professionalism, skill, diligence, prudence and foresight which would reasonably and ordinarily be expected from a skilled and experienced person engaged in the same type of activity under the same or similar circumstances; Group / Group Company: means Worldpay and any holding company of Worldpay and any subsidiary of such holding company from time to time and for the purposes of this definition "holding company" and "subsidiary" shall have the meaning given to those terms in section 1159 and Schedule 6 of the Companies Act 2006; Implementation Plan: means the timetable for the delivery of the Services and the Deliverables, together with the applicable Milestones as set out in or attached to each Statement of Work; Insolvency Event: means in relation to either Party: (a) the Party becomes unable to pay its debts as they fall due, or the value of the Party's assets is less than the amount of its liabilities, taking into account its contingent and prospective liabilities; (b) a petition is presented, an order made or a resolution passed for the liquidation (otherwise than for the purposes of a solvent amalgamation or reconstruction), administration, bankruptcy or dissolution of the Party; (c) an administrative or other receiver, manager, trustee, liquidator, administrator or similar person or officer is appointed to the Party and/or over all or any part of the assets of the Party; (d) the Party enters into or proposes any composition or arrangement concerning its debts with its creditors (or any class of its creditors) generally; or (e) anything equivalent to any of the events or circumstances stated in (a) to (d) inclusive occurs in any applicable jurisdiction; Intellectual Property Rights: means (a) patents, inventions, designs, copyright and related rights, database rights, trade marks and related goodwill, trade names (whether registered or unregistered), know-how, trade secrets and rights to apply for registration; (b) proprietary rights in domain names; (c) V3 Page 2 of30 applications, extensions and renewals in relation to any of these rights; and (d) all other rights of a similar nature or having an equivalent effect anywhere in the world (including the development, modification, or creation of any software); Invention: means any invention, idea, discovery, development, business method, formula, pattern, compilation, improvement or innovation made by the Supplier as a result of the provision of the Services, (including the development, modification, or creation of any Software) whether or not patentable or capable of registration; Key Personnel: means a fist of Personnel who are essential for the performance of the Services, as set out In a Statement of Work; Law: means all laws and regulations in force and applicable to a Party in respect of its rights and obligations under this Agreement, including any order of a court of competent jurisdiction and the rules or directions of any Regulatory Authority; Losses: means liabilities, claims, proceedings, judgments, damages, demands, actions, costs, charges, expenses, penalties, fines and any other loss of whatever nature, including court costs and reasonable legal fees; Material: means any document, methodology or process, Deliverable, data or other material in whatever form relating to the Services, including, any reports, specifications, business rules or requirements, user manuals, user guides, operations manuals, training materials and instructions; Milestone: means a group of events, tasks and Deliverables identified as such and described in the Implementation Plan or a Statement of Work which must be completed by a Milestone Date; Milestone Date: means the date agreed by the parties for the Acceptance of all Deliverables forming a Milestone, as set out in a Statement of Work; Party: means each party to this Agreement or, if different, a Statement of Work; Personal Data: has the meaning given to that term in the Data Protection Act 1998; Personnel: means any person employed or otherwise engaged by the Supplier or its subcontractor(s) in connection with the provision of the Services (in each case, whether pursuant to an employment contract, contract for the provision of services or subcontract); Pre-Contractual Statements: has the meaning set out in clause 20.12; Processing: has the meaning given to that term in the Data Protection Act 1998; Records: means: (a) ail financial records pertaining to expenses incurred and invoiced by the Supplier under this Agreement; and (b) complete and accurate timesheets and accounting records in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles to support and document all expenses incurred and invoiced by the Supplier and becoming payable to the Supplier under this Agreement; Regulatory Authority: means any governmental or regulatory authority, department, agency, commission, board, tribunal, crown corporation, or other law, rule or regulation-making entity that any of the Parties submit to or are subject to the jurisdiction of in respect of this Agreement, and any successor or replacement of any of the foregoing; Security Tests: means test procedures including tests of IT general controls, tests of IT application controls, IT risk assessments, penetration tests, compliance scans and vulnerability scans; Service Credits: means the amount payable by the Supplier to Worldpay for any failure to achieve the Service Levels, as set out in a Statement of Work; Service Levels: means the standard to which the Services are to be performed, as set out in a Statement of Work; Services: means the services set out in each Statement of Work; Software: means any software, computer program, programming language, codes or scripts developed or provided by the Supplier pursuant to this Agreement or a Statement of Work; Specification: the written specification for the Services or the Deliverables, as set out or attached to a Statement of Work; Statement of Work: means a contract agreed and executed by authorised signatories of both Parties in respect of the provision of the Services (or any amendment or variation of existing Services) in a form V3 Page 3 of30 materially as set out in Schedule 2; Term: means the duration of this Agreement as set out in clause 2, including any extensions agreed between the parties; Third Party Materials: means any materials forming part of the Works including any software, hardware, images or designs which are owned or controlled by a third party; Virus: means any software program or code intended to destroy, Interfere with, corrupt, or cause undesired effects on program files, data or other information, executable code or application software macros, whether or not Its operation is immediate or delayed; Works: means all records, reports, documents, papers, drawings, designs, transparencies, photos, graphics, logos, typographical arrangements, software, Deliverables and all other materials in whatever form, including but not limited to hard copy and electronic form, prepared by the Supplier during the course of the provision of the Services; and Worldpay Equipment: means any equipment, facilities or software provided by Worldpay and set out in a Statement of Work. In this Agreement: 1.2 the clause, schedule and paragraph headings are for convenience only and shall not affect the interpretation of this Agreement; 1.3 references to clauses are to clauses in the main body of this Agreement, and references to paragraphs are to paragraphs of the schedules; 1.4 any reference to persons includes natural persons, firms, partnerships, limited liability partnerships, companies, corporations, unincorporated associations, local authorities, governments, states, foundations and trusts (in each case whether or not having separate legal personality) and any agency of any of the above; BUSINESS CONTINUITY AND FORCE MA3EURE 17.1 The Supplier will ensure that at all times it has in place and is able to implement a business continuity and disaster recovery plan ("BCDR Plan") in accordance with its terms. If required, the Supplier will explain to Worldpay how the features set out in the BCDR Plan will interface with any business continuity and disaster recovery plans and procedures of Woridpay notified to the Supplier from time to time. 17.2 The Supplier shall develop, update and test the BCDR Plan on a regular basis and, in any event, not less than once in every twelve (12) month period, in accordance with Good Industry Practice. 17.3 Upon a request from Worldpay the Supplier shall, within thirty (30) days of any test of the BCDR Plan send to Worldpay a written report summarising the results of the test and shall promptly implement any actions or remedial measures which Woridpay considers necessary as a result of those tests. 17.4 The Supplier will permit Worldpay to have sight of the BCDR Plan upon reasonable notice at any time.
